Safe HaskellSafe-Inferred

SelectionFunctions.NQueens

Description

We have a N x N chess board. Two players take turns placing queens on the board. On i-th turn a queen must be placed in i-th column so that previously placed queens are not attacking it. This module can be used to calculate optimal moves using selection functions implemented as described in paper What Sequential Games, the Tychonoff Theorem and the Double-Negation Shift have in Common, 2010, by Martin Escardo.

  • type Move = Int
  • type Position = (Int, Int)

Documentation

n :: IntSource

Board size.

type Move = IntSource

Move is the number of column in which a queen is placed.

type Position = (Int, Int)Source

Coordinates on the board.

type R = BoolSource

Type of truth values that represent game outcomes.

attacks :: Position -> Position -> BoolSource

Call attacks p1 p2 checks if a queen in position p1 attacks position p2.

valid :: [Position] -> BoolSource

Function that checks if placement of queens on given positions is valid.

p :: [Move] -> RSource

Predicate on move sequences which tests the validity of resulting queen placement.

epsilons :: [[Move] -> J R Move]Source

List of history depentent selection functions of moves, where k-th selection function returns optimal move on k-th turn.

optimalPlay :: [Move]Source

Optimal play for NQueens.

optimalOutcome :: RSource

Optimal outcome of NQueens

optimalStrategy :: [Move] -> MoveSource

Returns an optimal move, given previous moves.

delete :: Ord x => x -> [x] -> [x]Source

Function that removes an element from an ordered list.

setMinus :: Ord x => [x] -> [x] -> [x]Source

Call setMinus xs ys returns a list with elements of xs that are not contained in ys.
